Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Colin, and other interested members,

Perhaps you might join the Human-Agen=
t-Robot-Teamwork (HART) workshop next year. Or, join the Agent Based Modeli=
ng and Simulation at SwarmFest June 28 - 30 in Santa Fe, NM.

There is so m=
uch more to NEAT than originally meets the eye - leading some of us to semi=
-autonomous forms of neuro-computation on hybrid, heterogeneous compute clu=
sters, for example. This is part of what I am presenting as SwarmFest. The =
Agent represents either human intelligence, or weak AI, such has the patter=
ns discovered and embedded in CPPNs from HyperNEAT. This is important to HA=
RT. As in Checkers, Chess or other higher forms of contextual pattern recog=
nition, what the Agent learns can often surpass the intelligence programmed=
 (trained) into it.  But, like humans, the Agent can always fall back on tr=
aining when trained fitness surpasses any novel patterns discovered.

I fou=
nd it a little humbling at first, now its just an interesting Black Swan.  =
Rather than being on different wavelengths, let's just say we are describin=
g the same phenomena from differing perspectives.  I hope to get some time =
to model different approaches to HyperNEAT4CUDA this weekend. This whole th=
ing is like drinking from a fire hose.

Ken Lloyd


From: Colin Green 
Sent=
: Thursday, May 21, 2009 4:04 PM
To: neat@yahoogroups.com 
Subject: Re: [ne=
at] HyperNEAT4CUDA





Hi,

2009/5/20 Ken Lloyd <kalloyd@...>:
>
>=
 Another major piece of the puzzle is just standard graph theory stuff, the=

> layout of network nodes where both distance and weight are evolved.  I'v=
e
> been using Graph Drawing with Intelligent Placement (GRIP - see Pavel G=
ajier
> and Steven Kobourov's work at U of Arizona).  This describes the SA=

> and maximal independent sets necessary to locate large numbers of nodes =
and
> describe the graph thermodynamics.
> http://citeseer.ist.psu.edu/gaje=
r02grip.html

I don't really follow, is this some scheme to chose node coor=
dinates
on the hyperneat substrate rather than using fixed points.

>
> The=
 critical, final piece of the puzzle is the application of Inverse Theory
>=
 to Neuro Evolution of Augmenting Topologies.  This is in answer to your
> =
question: "What do you refine towards? e.g. when evolving a
> controller wi=
th no defined 'correct' output?"

To me this definitely seems to be in the =
same ballpark as RBMs, that
is, we can train a neural net based on how accu=
rately it models the
data from a stochastic point of view. We don't have to=
 e.g. backprop
error values calculated against specific output targets, ins=
tead we
pump noise into the high level feature nodes and monitor the freque=
ncy
with which certain output patterns occur. This gives us an objective
ev=
aluation of the how well the domain in question is modelled. Now to
date I'=
m only aware of modelling of simple imput-output relationships
such as hand=
writing recognition, but it should be possible to evaluate
(and indeed trai=
n) a model of a dynamic system (e.g. a robot arm that
picks up and moves an=
 object). The stochastic patterns are now spread
out over time and thus the=
 weight update rules are more complex, but
it's theoretically possible. Qui=
te how this fit in with HyperNEAT I'm
not sure, I suppose HyperNEAT can act=
ually evolve very complex
topologies if you take all connection weights bel=
ow some value to be
not present, this trimmed down set of connections might=
 then be
trained using the RBM-like update rules.

> The problem I have of =
describing the interrelationship of all the above with
> HyperNEAT is "it's=
 all entangled, and interrelated" - meaning it
> works precisely like a TWE=
ANN.  I've been working with NEAT devices for over
> eight years, Kohonen S=
OFM before that - and I wish I could more precisely
> describe their behavi=
or in deterministic terms.  I can't. I can describe
> them mathematically i=
n probabilistic terms, but that isn't very satisfying
> to most folks.

Or =
most folks need to understand probabilistic models better, since
that's whe=
re all the interesting/promising AI developments seem to be.
:)

Ken, I fee=
l like I'm on a different wavelength to you a lot of the
time but you sure =
get the old brain cells working :)

Colin.
